												Alright, Dawn of War Dark Crusade, where to begin? This game is by far the best Dawn of War game to date, including Dawn of War 2 and its expansions. If you're an RTS fan, there is little here not to like. (Also, you don't need to own the original Dawn of War OR Winter Assault to enjoy this game)The gameplay is simple and very fun, you start out with a base and a builder unit, you proceed to make buildings filling various roles such as research, unit creation, and defense. You proceed to make a base and units to defend yourself, and you eventually attack the enemy. You have two resources, power and requisition, power is used for vehicles, upgrades and research, requisition is used for everything. Requisition is easy to get, just capture points across the map and fortify them with listening posts. Power requires you to create power generators, but bases have a limited amount.Campaign is simple, you pick a race, and you are given a map divided into territories, each territory is provides you honor guard (Elite units to defend your commander) and a planetary requisition bonus (to buy honor guards or defenses for territories, or buildings if you get a specific plot of land) The map is turn based, with you and the 6 other AI going to territories and trying to claim them, when you attack or defend a territory, you are put into a basic RTS battle. If you win, you get/keep the territory, and whatever buildings you made (not research, though) on that territory. You are also rewarded for attacking/defending, allowing you to get wargear for your commander. Your commander can equip new items that can change your playstyle with him/her or simple make them better. Now, the best part of campaign is the stronghold missions, these missions are when you attack another race's main territory, so instead of destroy the enemy HQ, you are presented other tasks, such as destroy these artillery units to stop part of the map being bombarded or kill this commander and get these soldiers to fight for you. Strongholds are very long, hard and entertaining. The game has a nice selection of races, each filling a playstyle.Tau = Strong ranged units, good offenseEldar = Stealth based, fast movingOrks = Melee swarmImperial Guard = Ranged Swarm, great tanksSpace Marines = All around, good melee and rangedChaos = Kinda like Space Marines, Melee focusedNecrons = Slow as hell, turtling, but can be near unstoppable when they do attackMultiplayer and Skirmishing is fun, pretty basic for an RTS but with bots or people, and your own rules.The graphics and sounds are nice, the graphics show battles in their full glory, with colorful explosions and blood flying from units, and the sound includes powerful gunfire and units yelling in battle. Not much more to be said, the game looks pretty and sounds like war. The soundtrack I do give a shoutout to, its very nicely done.The only real thing I have a problem with this game is the crashing I get. Sometimes in a match or on the menus my game just freezes up or crashes on me, its not common, but commen enough to add it to this review. I think RTS or Warhammer fans will really like this game, given you didn't buy it already, 9/10, great game, but some crashing and freezing stops it from being perfect.Also check out the mods for this game, some of them are very nifty.

												Dark Crusade was probably my favorite RTS throughout my college years.  While my friends were busy playing Starcraft, commanding the forces of Terrans, Protoss, and Zerg, I was busy fighting wars in the 41st Millennium, taking on foes ten times my greater and defeating them with honor and earning glory. Any RTS player would be a fool to deny that this game stood the test of time.  Stop reading the review, fork out some cash or grab that debit/credit card, and get the sodding game. Let's keep this game alive.  For the Emperor!

												Dark Crusade is an improvement on the mechanics of Dawn of War and adds new factions, units, and a world map-based conquest mode as the campaign in the game.  For those of us who enjoyed standard scenarios and multiplayer this is entirely an improvement.  Unfortunately, for those of us who were more caught up in the story-based campaigns where a story unfolded before you as you played, that feature no longer exists.The world map does offer a few advantages that I will admit are enjoyable.  First off, you feel more like a true commander as opposed to a company leader in the prior Dawn of War iterations.  You decided on where and when battles will take place and often those decisions are based on which provinces offer the most requisition (currency) and benefits for your units.  The enemy also acts with the same goals and will actively invade your territory if it sees fit, bringing the battle to you.The unfortunate part to this, in addition to the loss of a well developed story from earlier campaigns, most of your battles end up being frantic zerg fights where you churn out your units and upgrades as fast as possible and slam them into the enemy until they are dead.  Obviously, the old strategies do apply, and the classic rock-paper-scissors aspects of the units remain, but I myself always felt more caught up accomplishing objectives and advancing the story.It was a toss up for me, as you may have guessed after reading the above, but I have decided that I'm going to recommend this game since it will satisfy previous DoW players who enjoyed the basic scenarios even if the heavily story-based campaign is gone.

												Dark Crusade was, in my opinion, the best game of the Dawn of War series. It gave players more freedom than the previous two games with its multiple factions, while not suffering from the recycled concepts and poor storyline/voice acting of Soulstorm. The RISK style dynamic is one that I have found inherently fascinating, and one that I hope that Total War: Warhammer will exploit in the future. My personal highlight of the game, and probably the series overall, were the stronghold assaults. With entertaining storylines and objectives that make it feel very much like a special mission in the tabletop game, I found them to be a refreshing and rewarding experience. My one gripe is what seems to have been faction favouritism amongst the production team. Multiplayer combat is made less enjoyable when people play as the Eldar, and make their webway gate invisible, warping it all over the map, and forcing you to adopt time-consuming  strategies to beat. Overall, however, the game rates among my personal favourite RTSs. 9.5/10

												Warhammer 40,000: Dawn Of war: Dark Crusade: Black Scuffle is pretty cool I guess. Set in the distant future of the 41st Mellenia, Mankind has decided to show aliens just whos the boss of this gym by beating them all up. 10,000 years after their Jesus figure got cripple, humanity now has to fight an endless war across the stars for total domination against aliens and other humans that don't like them very much. The planet Kronus, located on the edge of an alien empire known as the Tau, has suddenly been thrown into an all out war between numerous different factions. The Tau themselves, a highly advanced alien race that relies on ranged weaponry and the help of other aliens for close combat, basically the nerds of the 40k world. The Imperial Guard, regular humans who fight with flash lights and balls of titanium. They also have big tanks and scary men who wear cool hats.The Eldar space elves who think they're smart but actually aren't. They also accidentally spawned a chaos god a few thousand years ago because they wouldn't stop having planetary scale murder orgies.  So like they're ones to talk about short comings of other races.They suck, I hate them.The Necrons, grumpy robot skeletons who were awoken because of all the gosh dang racket going on up stairs. Now want to destroy all life.Orks, space fungus soccer hooligans that can't stop shooting and punching everything. They're fun guys to be around.The forces of Chaos, evil humans that worship the gods of Chaos. Like to summon daemons (it's spelled like that in game) and get into bar fights. They're jerks. And of course there are the poster boys, the Space Marines, roided up super jocks that are like 8 feet tall and poop pure rage. Each race battles for control of the planet, trying to accomplish their own goals and thwart the plans of others by sitting down and discussing the matter like civil adults.I made that up. They kill each other hardcore.Now, I bought this game at launch, over the years I've accumulated about a hundred hours or so all together and only recently got a CD key from Sega for the steam version after Relic servers shut down. Dawn of war is more or less a traditional style RTS with a focus on base building. It's big thing is that your main resource comes from nodes you need to capture and secure on the map instead of building farms or something like that. This means that there is always a threat of combat as your enemies head out and attempt take points from you, furthering their resource gain while crippling yours. It's an aggressive way of playing that makes you constantly push your units forward instead of just turtling in your base.There is also a toggle for most units that lets them switch between ranged combat and melee combat, giving you another layer of strategy. There are units that specialize in ranged combat and units that specialize in giving wedgies and shoving you in a locker. It adds another layer of strategy as how to build your army. Your firewarriors may have a powerful ranged attack, but sooner or later those angry green rioters are going to reach your firing line, and then you'll look silly. Good thing you have these goofy bird looking guys that like to hit things with sticks, so you can happily fire away while your Kroot friends literally eat their enemies.  Gross. Single player is actually pretty neat. Instead of having a mission to mission story, you instead fight over the planet in a risk-style fashion. Each army has a pre-set number of locations where they can use points to reinforce their territory and buy special units for their army. While it can get kind of dull fighting for the same territory, it makes up for it with the stronghold missions of each faction acting like a more traditional kind of RTS mission. The voice acting is...Pretty friggin great. It's like a bunch of Shakespearean B-actors yelling mad banter at one another. This all being said, should you play Dim Expedition? It's pretty great, it adds a bunch of stuff to the last two games while also having a really neat competitive aspect in the form of multiplayer. If you can get it on the cheap, you should do so, but chances are you already have this game, considering how old it is.Dark Crusade gets 4 aliens yelling at one another out of 5. 												Dark Crusade is the second expansion to Dawn of War and advertised as a standalone expansion as well. It should however, not really be played as a standalone. The complete absence of any sort of tutorial or incremental introduction of units and technologies makes this an incredibly hard place to start for new players as you're essentially thrown into the deep end from the get go and just hope you learn how to swim before you get overwhelmed. To add insult to injury you can only use the two new races in multi-player unless you already own Dawn of War and Winter Assault.The two new races are very nice additions however. The Necrons are a pure powerhouse, the immortal machine servants of a long dead empire, serving vicious and hungry gods. In game they play quite differently from the others, ignoring usual resources and tactics their build speed is determined by the number of strategic points you own making them a very slow starter, to compensate their units are unusually tough and sometimes even resurrects themselves upon death. Lategame they transform into a steamroller as even their Headquarters becomes a flying, teleporting doomsday machine.The second new faction to be introduced is the Tau and they similarly play differently from the old factions although not quite as big a deviation as the Necrons are. The Tau are a strange mix of specialists, heavily armed but poorly armored weapons platforms and a variety of beastly allies. The biggest difference between them and other factions is the lategame choice of either going to the heavily armed but poorly armed weapons platforms or the huge beast allies they can also summon as choosing one path excludes the other.The single-player changes gear from the previous installments and replaces the linear and scripted missions of Dawn of War and Winter Assault with an open campaign map in a Grand Strategy style. Each faction starts with a stronghold province and must conquer the rest of the map as you play along gaining various bonuses from their conquests including various pieces of wargear for their leader. The problem with this concept is all the maps in between the various strongholds are just plain boring, both in attack an defense. Although the map changes it all plays much the same and it comes down to pure grind very quickly.The stronghold attacks however is where the game gets interesting. Challenging maps with multiple sub-objectives and small video sequences before and after makes them the only bright side of the new campaign.In terms of graphics and sound it maintains the same quality as the main game. A thunderhammer still makes a satisfying thump when impacting a traitor's breastplate and the Ork's still scream out their one word with relentless fervor.That feel that comes from the WH40K universe still exists, but the grind of the campaign makes it have much less of an impact than in the original. Still a good expansion, just not an exceptional one and definitely not one to be played as a standalone game.

												In the grim dark future of the 41st millennium, there is only war.In this standalone expansion to the epic series of electronic games known as Dawn of War, you can command armies of the Tau and fight for the Greater Good, or take control of the sinister Necrons and destroy all that crosses your path.Well, that's my lacklustre "epic introduction" done. Dawn of War - Dark Crusade adds the Tau and Necrons to the list of playable factions. While you can play as any faction introduced in Dawn of War or Dawn of War - Winter Assault in single player, unless you have both those games you can only play Tau or Necrons in multiplayer. Apparently there's a mod for this but I'm not entirely sure it's legal, so I don't have it. Being banned isn't much fun, and I like Tau anyway.The campaign uses a RISK-style map, and you must conquer the planet Kronus and drive all other factions off it. This being Warhammer, all the factions are lunatics, to a greater or lesser degree. If you're unfamiliar with Warhammer, stop. Why are you unfamiliar with Warhammer?The available factions in this game, for those of you who for some reason are unfamiliar with Warhammer 40,000 or its fantasy counterpart, are:The Tau. Blue space communist who fight for the Greater Good. Useless in melee.The Space Marines, super-buff guys in powered armour. Nicknamed Catholic Space Nazis.The Imperial Guard, the less-superpowered allies of the Space Marines. Technically part of the same faction, but they're separate armies so whatever.The Eldar, high-tech space elves on the brink of extinction. Ridiculously overpowered in this game, since they can literally turn their whole base invisible and field ridiculous amounts of troops.The Orks, fungus-based humanoids who just want to kill stuff for fun. Completely ridiculous but oddly endearing, they run partly on duct tape and space magic.The Necrons, Egyptian-themed immortal robots who hate everything living.Chaos, a collection of space demons who worship evil gods. Evil by Warhammer standards, and there are Warhammer factions that make Adolf Hitler look like someone's grandfather. Unless of course he is your grandfather, in which case I apologise.Now, if you had to have all that explained to you, go and study Warhammer 40,000. You scrub.*The game is an RTS, since it's based on a tabletop wargame, and quite a good one. Instead of training individual units, you train squads. The graphics are a bit outdated and make some of the units look silly (Chaos Marines look adorable, for some reason) but having played Minecraft, literally anything is a step up. Boy do I love bashing Minecraft.Pathfinding occasionally throws a tantrum and units randomly mill around before moving on to the point where you want them to go, but apart from that the game is generally fun to play and well-balanced, if a little outdated. Unless of course you count Eldar, who are ridiculously overpowered.If you're a fan of Warhammer, and you like the Tau or Necrons, I'd recommend this game.*Please note that this is all said as a joke. Most people will know this, but there a few people who will leap to the comments section to rant about me calling non-Warhammer fans "scrubs".

Eventually, Dawn of War 1 had a similar patch, removing the Gamespy roots.  LAN mode was sacrificed in the process, a sad exclusion from the new version, but nonetheless I feel that it was a great move to continue support for the game.BUT IT DIDN'T STOP THERE. 												I rate the game Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War - Dark Crusade 4/5. Good. This is far more than a simple add-on to the largely mediocre Dawn of War. This is an excellent and fairly vast expansion. In terms of its overall structure, this is probably the best Command and Conquer style "RTS" (Real Time Strategy as they are called, though applying the term "strategy" to this kind of game may be a little bit of a misnomer as most "RTS" games includes relatively little actual strategy but more often merely include certain tactical elements) I have ever played. It's most notable strengths are that it allows you to play as one of many different, unique factions, each faction has its own ending and the global-scale battle map allows the single-player campaign to give you, the player, a great many choices as you attempt to progress through the war.But this game is not without flaws. Indeed, this game, particularly the single-player campaign, has some fairly serious flaws.An example of The Good (if not Great):+The single player campaign map gives you excellent strategic options. Remember the old between-mission battle maps that were found in some of the oldest Command and Conquer games? This mode works a lot like that but instead of letting you select either one battle or another, your options are much more varied. If you capture the sector which has the spaceport your options become even more numerous because then you can attack most places across the globe. Likewise, capturing certain other sectors gives your forces certain other strategic and tactical benefits which make an enormous difference as the campaign progresses. This between-mission global strategic map mode is a truly excellent feature which lets you choose how you want the single-player campaign to progress while showing you your options (or lack thereof) and letting you see how your campaign is progressing. It is a feature I would honestly like to see in every other "RTS" game ever made as it offers unparalleled choice and strategic options well beyond what most other similar such Command and Conquer style "RTS" games ever come close to offering you. The inclusion feature should set the bar higher for every other command and conquer style RTS to follow. For me, this feature (combined with the inclusion of the Tau as a fully playable faction) made the game for me and made me want to keep playing the main campaign through to its conclusion.The Mediocre:+/- This game requires you to make heavy use of your lightest infantry units. This severely limits the number of tactical options which ever become available to you while at once causing the body count in each battle to rise dramatically. This makes some sense for certain factions (like the Imperial Guard) but makes less since for other factions. Worse, the Imperial Guard factions still don't have unit sizes which seem to ever be large enough or populous enough while the Space marine units never seem to be durable enough for them to be remotely canonical. The Tau units take casualties far too often as well for them to be canonical. When playing as the Tau or the Eldar the game should penalize you (severely) for taking heavy casualties but it doesn't. All factions require you to heavily rely on infantry before building ANY tanks or other vehicles (making the game all too command and conquer styled for my tastes) and units do not seem to ever level up or gain any experience for being in combat which further decreases this game's tactical depth. Ideally, Imperial guard units should automatically include huge numbers of soldiers and some tanks should be available from the outset. Tau forces should heavily rely on tanks and their APC units from the outset. Necrons should be very, very, very slow (much slower than they are shown to be in this game) but almost indestructible. Space Marines should be much, much more durable but much, much fewer in number. (Remember, in Warhammer 40k, there is said to be fewer space marines than inhabited planets in the galaxy) and they cannot afford to lose the sheer numbers they lose in this game (and neither can the Tau or the Eldar or the Necrons). Since all the factions play so similarly to each other (and none of them truly play like they really should) the tactical options are severely limited as a result and the battles are, as a direct result, much, much more repetitious and uninteresting than they could have been. From what I can tell from reading a few of the Warhammer 40k codexes, what we have here in these Dawn of War games is not really Warhammer 40k, but something with its name that sort of looks like it but doesn't really feel much like it. Still, the world of Warhammer 40k is a big one and so there's some room for my suspension of disbelief. However, this game should also be highly commended for the sheer variety of factions which it attempted to include and everything it did well about each faction (especially their voices and sounds they make when responding to orders). The great many factions and thus the great many campaigns which this game includes greatly adds replay value to this game. My Tau campaign lasted over 30 hours. I'd imagine other campaigns would take just as long as well.The Bad:- The singleplayer campaign is blatantly unfair. In the single player campaign, battles wherein you attempt to attack and take over enemy strongholds or main bases all have additional, almost unfair objectives which must be completed. (I found the Necron main-base to be worst because the mission would automatically fail if you failed to get your little commander-unit out alive (and this is not true in any other battle and that particular battle tried hard to make this objective particularly difficult resulting in some frustration.) Now needing to complete extra objectives to take over an enemy base is fine, if the game was fair about it but this game isn't remotely fair about this-EVER. If an enemy attacks YOUR main base then you only have one or two little bases and all the CPU computer enemy has to do to make you lose the ENTIRE game is to destroy those one or two bases. The CPU must complete absolutely no other additional objectives to defeat you. To make matters worse, regardless of which side you play, in terms of number of main-bases you are very nearly always out-matched in every battle, whether you are attacking a main base or not. In the vast majority of battles in the main campaign the enemy has at least 2 main bases when I had just one (and I was playing on EASY difficulty. Indeed, One might think this kind of blatant, in-built unfairness is due to the game's essentially poor AI but this game doesn't seem to have poor AI. The enemy AI actually acted quite well. And, of course, on higher difficulties the AI responds more quickly and acts more aggressively. The AI is at least adequate to provide excellent challenges when all things are equal (though it is of course less creative than a person can potentially be). Honestly, I don't think that the kind of in-built unfairness that I mentioned above needed to exist in this game and it made for a needlessly frustrating experience. However, I should mention that RTS games are generally NOT my main forte. Unless I'm playing Homeworld Cataclysm, RTS games are games I am generally not very good at. Maybe there should be an option programmed in to make the main campaign blatantly unfair or not if those who are great at RTS games need additional challenges (something like a Pro or Expert mode).-Space Marines still look cute and huggable in this game (big feet, little heads, big shoulders, puppet-like animations).

												In the Emperors name, you will purchase this game.Whether you're a w40k fan or a real time strategy game fan, you'll love Dark Crusade.It's incredibly fun, you'll be charging into battle with your enemies, constantly repeating anything your units say.If you've played the original game of Dawn of War, you'll definitely feel at home with Dark Crusade, it's more of the same but much much better. Based on a world map that you can invade other provinces instead of following a campaign story is much better.The W40k universe is so huge and so fantastic that you'll be fascinated by the Imperium of Man with their Soldiers, or the God Emperors Space Marines, the dark necrons, or Chaos Space Marines... Or perhaps the Eldar or even the technological Tau with their Greater Good philosophy (or the orcs... but who likes them? ;) Haha).Set on the planet Kronus, you'll find yourself in the middle of a bloody war, a dark crusade. Where one faction will triumph and the total annihilation of all others. Make sure that it is YOUR faction. You can play as any of the W40k factions that you've grown to know and love... Or at least you'll come to know and love if you haven't experienced a W40k game yet though.Don't let the franchise fool you though, it's very easy to get into the frachnise, this was the first W40k game I've ever played (back in 2006) and I've played all of them since (and the ones before). I'm not a fan of the figures or the board game though, even though the games are based on it... Shh! Plus the CGI movies/clips are awesome. The whole W40k universe is fascinating.Anyway, about the game.It's a typical real time strategy game, construct buildings, construct units from buildings, defeat the enemy. That's a simple run down of it anyway. All of the maps are static too. So when you've built a base in a province, if you're invaded, your base will be exactly the same as it was when you first built it. But any buildings destroyed in the next battle will be gone, but also new buildings will stay obviously. So definitely plan ahead when you first build in a province. (SPOILER: I've found myself trapping an enemy in a small corner of a map and building a huge base all over the map before I destroy them, so that my huge base is persistant if anyone invades it... 												Dawn of War: Dark Crusade is arguably the best expansion in the series. It abandoned linearity within the campaign that it's predecessors had and replaced it with a Risk-like game. You have your own region on Kronus and your objective is to build up your army and conquer the other factions on the planet. It was fun, challenging, and refreshing. RTS games have never been good at conveying a story, so rather than waste time and money trying to create a story around characters that are emotionless superhumans built only for war, they went with a big map for you to have your own fun. This in my opinion was a smart decision and gave Relic more room to work with now that they don't have to create a narrative. There are of course the commanders that go back and forth with each other bickering about whose side is better. And while that may sound annoying, they actually did a really great job. The commanders feel like they have more personality and are commited to their cause while not putting the attention entirely on them individually. In my opinion, this was a step in the right direction. Because now the rest of the focus is on the military aspect of 40k (which has always been it's selling point). The Plot Kronus is an Imperium controlled world with a native population of Orks and a ever growing Tau civilization. This has caused many skirmishes throughout the planet's history and has awaken the long dorment Necron hordes. Eldar of Ulthwe come to intercept the Necrons and defeat them before they can fully reawake. Meanwhile the forces of Chaos, the Word Bearers legion arrive to take the planet of Kronus for their own sadistic needs in the name of the Chaos gods. The Orks, riled up more than ever now that there is a full planetary war want to sink their teeth on the battlefield. Led by the infamous Warboos Gorgutz, the Orks push into Tau and Imperium controlled regions to plunder the riches of the land and crush anything in their path.The Tau have called in reinforcements to respond to all of this discord. Taking full advantage of this war distracting their enemies, they are more than willing to take the planet for the greater good. And the Space Marines, mighty warriors of the God Emperor are locked in a conflict of interest with the Imperial Guard. The Guard, refusing to stand down and obey orders from the Space Marines have left the two factions of the Imperium fighting eachother in all out war. The Mutliplayer Because I covered the base factions in my last Dawn of War review I'm just going to talk about the Tau and Necrons. The Tau are a young race of aliens that have advanced in technology at an accelerating rate. Because of this they have access to mobile battle suits, advanced stealth technology, and raw fire power that can turn entire platoons of soldiers into nothing more but stains on the battlefield. I find them to be borderline over powered in Dark Crusade. They simply deal waaaay too much damage far too quickly. Have a decked out squad of Guardsmen? Not anymore! Their only Achilles heel is melee. Units like Chaos Raptors or Assault Marines can make short work of Tau Fire Warriors. The problem is, not all factions have melee units with jetpacks... Now a lot of people on the forums would strongly disagree with me that on-foot melee units like Banshees can get in Tau ranged lines. But if you are fighting an intelligent player that knows his or her weaknesses as Tau, those Banshees will be knocked down to a quarter of their squad size by the time they reach the Fire Warriors. And since most Tau players build two to three squads of Fire Warriors, expect them to be shooting the remaining Banshees.Other than just the insane amount of power they have, they're a decent faction. They lack defense turrets in their base, which means that if you attack a Tau base they have no other option but to send their forces back to support their base. This in my opinion is a reasonable weakness and doesn't make the Tau nigh unstoppable. Eldar can easily use this weakness to their advantage so it leaves some options.The Necrons....I don't know what's worse, the fact that they are completely broken or that they are possibly the most boring faction to play as. They're ungodly slow, have no satisfaction to their gameplay whatsoever, and they are so hard to kill that it makes easter egg hunts for Eldar bases at the end of a game look fun. If you are new to Dawn of War DO NOT play Necrons first. They will suck all of the fun you could be having in the game out of you leaving you with a bitter taste in your mouth. Necrons are however fun to play against with friends in team games. But outside of being just a good bad guy to fight, they aren't worth playing. Unless of course you want to be a troll and ruin everyone's day with Pariah's. The Final Verdict It's a 9/10. The campaign was great, some of the balance changes for the other factions were decent, and the two new factions were a welcomed addition despite the questionable balance behind them. However because of the two additional factions and their balance issues I have to count it as a negative. It's like no one at Relic thought about it "oh yeah! Space terminators that can never die and are slow as ♥♥♥♥ to progress with will be fun!" The lack of mods is also unfortunate because that means you have to get Soulstorm for mods like Ultimate Apocolypse. But overall Dark Crusade is a must buy if you are getting the base game of Dawn of War.PS: As always leave a comment if you have an opinion on the review or how to make it better. I'm always interested to hear from other perspectives.

												Yes, yes, yes.This is the best RTS I have ever played. I usually don't like RTS but I absolutely LOVE Dawn of War. This game has such an immersive, epic, dark and warmongering feel to it. You just enter battle and you hear the Ork soundtrack start with the drums and all in your mind is "Cleanse! Purge! KILL!"This game doesn't feature all the races in Warhammer 40k but it does feature most of them, and the ones left out have been implemented into the game by modders, such as Tyranids. Relic surprised me with how accurate this is to the lore and the tabletop game. Even the resource costs of troops is the same as the cost for troops on the tabletop (in the tabletop you have X amount of points to spend in a battle for your troops and more powerful troops cost more points). I haven't actually played the Dawn of War and Winter Assault campaigns because I think linear RTS campaigns are among the most boring things in this whole world, but Dark Crusade features a unique and awesome campaign mode. (Soulstorm has this campaign aswell but in much larger scale.)You start the campaign by choosing one of the races; Space Marines, Orks, Eldar, Chaos Space Marines, Tau, Necrons or Imperial Guard. All the races control different areas on a planet and then take turns assaulting other's areas with your hero, conquering them, gaining resources and honour guard (units that accompany your leader in battle who are more powerful than normal units) to spend on buying troops for all your areas or buying honour guard units. You can also unlock new gear for your hero, such as new ranged or melee weapons, better armor that give different perks, certain gear gives abilities like teleport and such, and to eradicate a race you have to assault their strongholds, and those battles have lots of different objectives and side objectives you have to do to win, like destroying different bases and if you want to, destroying bases that provide certain powerful units for the enemy so that the final push will be easier. I remember when I tried to take the Tau stronghold as Space Marine and the battle went on for like 1½ hour because they just kept harassing my base.If you want a hell of a good RTS in one of the coolest, if not the coolest sci-fi universe out there, then this is totally the game for you. I'm not sure if it's still here but there's a platinum version of the game to buy which gives you Dawn of War, Winter Assault and Dark Crusade for 9,99€, I can't find it anymore though. If you manage to find it and you're a RTS fan, then do buy it because it's more than worth it, I assure you.

												I really like this game and I just finished the campaign a moment ago (for the Blood Ravens). Dawn of War Dark Crusade is an expansion to Relic's real time strategy game Dawn of War, which is set in the Warhammer 40, 000 universe of table top wargames. I highly recommend it to any real time stategy fan who loves the grittines and toughness of battles which are primarily set in a distopian future where every alien you meet wants to kill you and eat you for jujubes :D, and that's not all; Your government, which is the Grand Imperium of Man, constantly drafts new recruits in the billions in order to sacrifice to The Emeperor, who uses His powerful psychic mind in order to stave the forces of Super Hell (or Chaos for short) which constantly gobbles up any known dangerous substances in order to get high for the dark gods. The 7 major races are The Blood Ravens; The Emperor's own space marines who came to the planet Kronus to search for the secrets of their lost history. The Ork's or should I say 'Da Orks', only come for the tendency of following their Ork Chieftains for the sake of the Waaaagh!!!! in order to satuate their cravings for constant battle. The Eldar, a mysterious alien race which are a splinters of their former empire 10, 000 years prior to the 41st millenium, have come to Kronus in order to stop their ancient enemies, known as the Necrons, from rising from their tomb worlds and purging the galaxy clean of all sentient life. The Necrons were metallic warriors who slumbered eons ago iduring the aftermath, which in Eldar legend was in the aftermath of the so called 'War in Heaven'. Then there are the imperial guard, chaos and the tau (my favourite), and for that YOU can explore for yourself. For the 4 races I've mentioned there is a ton of lore to explore and unfortunately I cannot tell you all of it. If you think Halo, Startrek  and Starwars had tons of lore, you have never read the Lore of 40k, it is just a massive game world that you need to delve into. As for this game I give a solid 9/10. Please relic in the name of the emperor, where is Dawn of War 3?

  WAAAAAUUGHIt's not a bad game and it actually makes the war feel like a war. If you like RTS's this game needs to be in your collection.  If you are new to RTS's this is a good middle of the road game to wet your feet with. There are better games but this is a good game in its own right.You fight against other races for control of provinces which you must then defend and so on..  Quite nice and unique for an RTS of the time. Only problem is this makes it rather shallow in the story department.Where else is this game shallow, Game play. There is a finite number of distinct races an RTS can have and that number seems to be about 4.  There are 7 playable factions in this game and only about 3 playstyles between them. You'll very quickly figure out  the optimal squad composition and never have a reason to vary from it. So the game play is a little shallow. Fun, but shallow .One glaring negative though is the cheating. Now it's a given that RTS games cheat a little. This one cheats a lot and quite brazenly at that. See there is a unit cap imposed, and this will always make missions dicey. Now I should explain there is a bonus called Forward Base , that allows you to start any attack mission with certain basic structures already build, for a fee. As far as the PC is concerned. It always has forward base active regardless of whether or not he obtained the bonus.. Whether you attack or defend the enemy will always have two pre-built bases.  Remember the unit cap I mentioned. Well each of these two bases basically counts as an individual player. so the end eresult is that the enemy will always have double the unit cap you do and this includes elite hero units as well. Never mind that for some of the races there are certain structures that the pc is allowed to place in ways that are outright against the gamne's rules . The Tau listening post upgrades can only be built  on strategic points when you control the tau. When you fight against the Tau you will find these defense turrets placed and where the pc wants. So the game cheats, hard.If you don't mind the cheating however, the game is pretty fun. It's a great spectacle RTS.  The combat and skirmishes are always fun to watch and the reenforcement mechanic means you have to keep a close eye on your units and  thusly keeps the battles quite engaging.All in all this is a decent RTS. Not as good as the Blizzard RTS's or THe Red Alert games , but a solid RTS in its own right.  Give it and the other expansions a try. So far I can recomend this over Soulstorm, the next game in the series, because, to be honest,  It has a tighter focus and the factions have a more unique feel.

												Dark Crusade was probably my favorite RTS throughout my college years. While my friends were busy playing Starcraft, commanding the forces of Terrans, Protoss, and Zerg, I was busy fighting wars in the 41st Millennium, taking on foes ten times my greater and defeating them with honor and earning glory. This was also the version of Warhammer 40K's Dawn of War series that got me into modding, giving me a sweet, sweet taste of what the penultimate prize of Modding experience would be promised to me upon getting Soulstorm.If you've ever gotten the previous two, Dawn of War and Winter Assault, you'd know gameplay-wise that nothing's really changed. However, with the addition of two new factions; the popular Necrons and the mysteriuos Tau Empire; and new units for all other factions (including Grey Knights for the Blood Ravens, which remains my favorite unit choice to this day), it definitely shines in front of its predecessors. That, and with an awesome campaign where you can play not just one but all seven factions, promising continuous replayability even after you've beaten the campaign once...there's nothing here that's not to like.I'd be a fool not to recommend Dark Crusade. Any RTS player would be a fool to deny that this game stood the test of time. Stop reading the review, fork out some cash or grab that debit/credit card, and get the sodding game. The best part about it all is that the multiplayer options are compatible with all versions and are standalone, so you only need one game to have fun. I recommend giving it a go, it's worth it. Let's keep this game alive. For the Emperor

												Dark Crusade is arguably one of the greatest RTS games ever made, and is a triumph for the genre. Every RTS staple in present, in interesting and mechanically creative ways. No other RTS offers as much content and diversity. Although this, the second expansion to the primary game, features a Risk style campaign with little variance between races, it is still the most satisfying and complete. With SEVEN playable races, each with entirely diferent tech trees and gameplay mechanics, no other game can compete. This is better than Starcraft, dare I say it. Note that it features Squad based combat, in that you control groups of infantry units (Company of Heros is the spiritual sucessor from the same publisher). This allows for massive conflicts that are still manageable and allow for micro-management of abilities. Fans of macro- and micro-management can be equally effective, as different races cater to different strengths.The interface is intuitive and translates easy across all playable races. The sound is impressive and chaotic. The graphics are, well, old. The multiplayer is obviously lacking in players the older the game gets, but is still occupied. A simple tracking system shows you (or warns you) just how good your online opponents will be, but it doesn't force a matchmaking system on you. Dark Crusade embodies everything good and wonderful in the RTS genre, and it is by far and away the best RTS money can buy. I cannot recommend it strongly enough.

												The Dark Crusade is considered the starting point in my campaign with the Warhammer series probably back in 2007. I always come back to this game year after year because I enjoy the single player and multiplayer game modes that include all the races unlocked out of the gate. The single player mode allows you to pick any race and drops you on the map with the rest of the races scattered across the globe. Each section of the map you win provides requisition and other bonuses to your army. The turn based "Risk style" mode begins after your first action and then allows each AI a turn in capturing territories. Similar to other RTS games, Dark Crusade is no different and allows you to construct buildings, vehicles and troops. The maps in each territory are littered with capture points that you will need to grab before your opponent in order to gain resources to expand your base. While there isn't much story in the campaign beyond the first introduction scene, more details will unfold as you begin to win battles against the other opponents when you capture their strongholds. The main character for each race is also outfitted with war gear as you fulfill certain requirements throughout Dark Crusade. Once you start conquering section of the map, rest assured that each race will take opportunites to invade and try to force you out of the territory. If I could recommend an RTS game then this would be the one out of all the Warhammer games. Whether it is a group of vehicles bombarding soldiers sending them flying or the up close action of Blood Ravens putting the boots to Orks for the Emperor, I feel there is never a dull moment in battle. I think Dark Crusade is the definitive pick over the newer Dawn of War games because of the maps, large scale battles and the non-linear campaign. Your best bet is to pick up the Warhammer collection, which usually pops up on sale. I had hours of time on Dark Crusade when I owned the original disc but had to purchase it again because I lost them.

												The definitive edition of Dawn of War, that still hasn't been surpassed, even by it's sequels. One of the best RTS games in the past 10 years, and I've almost been playing it that long. Pros: +Great entry point for everyone looking to get into Warhammer 40,000.+Seven races playable both in the Campaign and Skirmish modes...+...that all feel different and unique to each other. +Campaign features a "Wargear" system that lets you upgrade your Commander after certain achievements you get during the length of your campaign, adding an RPG feel to the game. (Ex: Conquer 3 territories, Have a 3:1 unit kill ratio...)+Great voice acting, truly stellar. +Inovative RTS mechanics, at least back when the game came out. Still, they stood and continue to stand the test of time. +Excellent graphics that continue to impress to this day. Especially the unit models, which rival the tabletop game Dawn of War is based on. +Like the Campaign, the Skirmish mode can offer a lot of variety, with good number of maps that can hold up to 8 players and the option to chose from multiple victory conditions (Ex: Destorying the enemy's HQ, Controlling certain points on the map for an amount of time, Assassinating the enemy commander...)+Army painter; A tool you can use to create a unique look for your favorite race. You can even import custom pictures as your army's banner.Cons: -The Easy difficulty in the Campaign is too easy, making your units have five times the health of your opponent's...-...while the other difficulties don't make the AI smarter, just decrease the difference in heatlh.-The Skirmish  AI also leaves something to be desired, as it doesn't get smarter after the "Standard" difficulty and instead resorts to cheating.  -Despite the excellent models and detail, some of the textures can look a bit muddy. -When moving in large groups, the unit pathing is horrible, with units moving backwards and vehicles getting stuck.-Some balancing issues. Overall rating: 8/10Highly recommended to RTS players and Warhammer fans alike.

												Dark Crusade is arguably one of the greatest RTS games ever made, and is a triumph for the genre. Every RTS staple in present, in interesting and mechanically creative ways. No other RTS offers as much content and diversity. Although this, the second expansion to the primary game, features a Risk style campaign with little variance between races, it is still the most satisfying and complete. With SEVEN playable races, each with entirely diferent tech trees and gameplay mechanics, no other game can compete. This is better than Starcraft, dare I say it. Note that it features Squad based combat, in that you control groups of infantry units (Company of Heros is the spiritual sucessor from the same publisher). This allows for massive conflicts that are still manageable and allow for micro-management of abilities. Fans of macro- and micro-management can be equally effective, as different races cater to different strengths.The interface is intuitive and translates easy across all playable races. The sound is impressive and chaotic. The graphics are, well, old. The multiplayer is obviously lacking in players the older the game gets, but is still occupied. A simple tracking system shows you (or warns you) just how good your online opponents will be, but it doesn't force a matchmaking system on you. Dark Crusade embodies everything good and wonderful in the RTS genre, and it is by far and away the best RTS money can buy. I cannot recommend it strongly enough.

												Warhammer 40k Dark Crusade is the 3rd entry into the Dawn of War series and its a strong contender in the RTS market despite not being as mainstream as the Starcraft or Stronghold series. If you enjoy games like Company of Heroes and Starcraft then this is a can't miss title.The game is set on the planet Kronus where the Imperial Guard rule in the name of the Emperor but all is not well on Kronus. The Ork invasion has begun anew on this planet and with all the fighting above the ancient killing machines known as the Necron have awaken which in turn has caused the Tau to appear on the planet in an effort to stop them from annihilating all life on the planet. Of course all this extra violence has attracted the attention of the Blood God of Chaos attention and brought the Chaos Marines onto Kronus. And with the Chaos Marines the Eldar quickly came in tow to stop them from ressurecting more demons and overtaking more planets. The Space Marines (namely the Blood Ravens) are ordered to cleanse the planet now for it is considered overrun with the Alien, the Unclean, and the Heretic. Upon their arrival on the planet they are told their are precious artifacts on Kronus that must be reclaimed at all costs and thus order the Imperial Guard to evacuate from Kronus in order for them to purge Kronus and reclaim the artifacts. The Guard promptly refuses and sparks an intense war with the Blood Ravens. This all quickly turns into a nasty open war.How this war plays out however is solely up to you however. The game gives you a decent background for each race and the events leading to the war but it has not true canon story beyond that. Your campaign mode consists of picking 1 of several races (Space Marines, Imperial Guard, Eldar, Orks, Chaos Marines, Tau, or Necrons) and then using them to conquer the entire map. The campaign starts off on the world screen where you can reinforce your territories launch attacks or upgrade your Honor Guard, which are essentially free beefed up versions of your basic units, as well as upgrade your commander unit with Wargear, items that add health attack or other bonus abilities to your commander unit. Each race has its own Stronghold which if taken will kick them from the game for that campaign. Capture all strongholds to win.All in all the game looks great despite some age, it sounds great and has a decent soundtrack and its positively steeped in lore for every race. Theres dozens of novels written on this series. I highly recommend this game to any and all fans of RTS games. Gotta cut this one short since Steam wont let me write any more about this game! For the Emperor!

												The Dark Crusade is considered the starting point in my campaign with the Warhammer series probably back in 2007. I always come back to this game year after year because I enjoy the single player and multiplayer game modes that include all the races unlocked out of the gate. The single player mode allows you to pick any race and drops you on the map with the rest of the races scattered across the globe. Each section of the map you win provides requisition and other bonuses to your army. The turn based "Risk style" mode begins after your first action and then allows each AI a turn in capturing territories. Similar to other RTS games, Dark Crusade is no different and allows you to construct buildings, vehicles and troops. The maps in each territory are littered with capture points that you will need to grab before your opponent in order to gain resources to expand your base. While there isn't much story in the campaign beyond the first introduction scene, more details will unfold as you begin to win battles against the other opponents when you capture their strongholds. The main character for each race is also outfitted with war gear as you fulfill certain requirements throughout Dark Crusade. Once you start conquering section of the map, rest assured that each race will take opportunites to invade and try to force you out of the territory. If I could recommend an RTS game then this would be the one out of all the Warhammer games. Whether it is a group of vehicles bombarding soldiers sending them flying or the up close action of Blood Ravens putting the boots to Orks for the Emperor, I feel there is never a dull moment in battle. I think Dark Crusade is the definitive pick over the newer Dawn of War games because of the maps, large scale battles and the non-linear campaign. Your best bet is to pick up the Warhammer collection, which usually pops up on sale. I had hours of time on Dark Crusade when I owned the original disc but had to purchase it again because I lost them.

												If you are a fan of either the Warhammer 40K universe, or RTS games, or both, then this game is for you. Out of all the Dawn of War games (excluding Dawn of War 2), this one is hands down my favorite. I have sunk a LOT of hours into this game, and I'm only about a quarter of the way finished with it.Here's how the game plays: You pick a race (Space Marines, Chaos, Tau, Ethereal, Orks, Imperial Guard) at the start of the game. Each race has their own strengths and weaknesses. My personal favorite are the Space Marines, who are very versatile and can easily adapt to any situation. Once you pick a race, the game begins. It is set up like a board game, similar to Risk. Each race takes a turn, and on your turn you can choose where you want to move to. Where you choose determines what race you will fight in that area. Every territory also rewards you with Honor Guard, which are elite units (VERY powerful compared to your regular units). In addition to this, there are a couple territories that have special abilities, such as the Spaceport that lets you attack anywhere, or Forward Base which lets you start matches with some buildings already made. The game continues on like this, with you attacking and defending. Your commander unit also acquires War Gear as you play, which makes them even more powerful.The real combat of this game is in the attacking or defending phase. The game plays as standard RTS fare. You gather resources, build structures, and grow your army. There is a lot of variety within a single race, which really helps to mix up the gameplay. You take over resource points and fortify them as your forces clash with your opponent. Once your army is built up enough, then you can obliterate your opponent and win the territory. Two things are important to remember, though. First, the way you leave a territory is what you will come back to when you are defending it. If you fortify it heavily, then you will be hard to defeat when the battle comes back to that area. Secondly, the special territories all have unique battles. The Spaceport, for example, has you gathering special units scattered across the map. The first side to collect 6 of these wins.Graphics wise, this game is behind what you'd expect from a modern RTS game, but it gets the job done very well. The units are all very detailed, and pleasing to look at when you zoom the camera in. The only downside is that the terrain looks a little bland sometimes. However, this game is not about looking pretty, it's about the battles. And combat is really well done in this game. If you've played the other Dawn of War games, then you know how it goes. It's really cool to see the animations of units in combat, they don't just pummel each other until a health bar is gone, there is interaction between clashing forces.In addition to the campaign, there is a skirmish mode that you can play to your heart's content. If you and a buddy have this game, then you can also jump online and play against each other in online multiplayer. All in all, this is a great game. Don't let Steam fool you, I've been playing this long before I bought it on here, and my hours in it are easily 200+. I like replaying the game as the other races to see what I've missed. If you like Warhammer 40K or RTS games, this one's for you. If you aren't sure, then grab it if it goes on sale. Trust me, it's worth it.

												Warhammer 40k Dark Crusade is the 3rd entry into the Dawn of War series and its a strong contender in the RTS market despite not being as mainstream as the Starcraft or Stronghold series. If you enjoy games like Company of Heroes and Starcraft then this is a can't miss title.The game is set on the planet Kronus where the Imperial Guard rule in the name of the Emperor but all is not well on Kronus. The Ork invasion has begun anew on this planet and with all the fighting above the ancient killing machines known as the Necron have awaken which in turn has caused the Tau to appear on the planet in an effort to stop them from annihilating all life on the planet. Of course all this extra violence has attracted the attention of the Blood God of Chaos attention and brought the Chaos Marines onto Kronus. And with the Chaos Marines the Eldar quickly came in tow to stop them from ressurecting more demons and overtaking more planets. The Space Marines (namely the Blood Ravens) are ordered to cleanse the planet now for it is considered overrun with the Alien, the Unclean, and the Heretic. Upon their arrival on the planet they are told their are precious artifacts on Kronus that must be reclaimed at all costs and thus order the Imperial Guard to evacuate from Kronus in order for them to purge Kronus and reclaim the artifacts. The Guard promptly refuses and sparks an intense war with the Blood Ravens. This all quickly turns into a nasty open war.How this war plays out however is solely up to you however. The game gives you a decent background for each race and the events leading to the war but it has not true canon story beyond that. Your campaign mode consists of picking 1 of several races (Space Marines, Imperial Guard, Eldar, Orks, Chaos Marines, Tau, or Necrons) and then using them to conquer the entire map. The campaign starts off on the world screen where you can reinforce your territories launch attacks or upgrade your Honor Guard, which are essentially free beefed up versions of your basic units, as well as upgrade your commander unit with Wargear, items that add health attack or other bonus abilities to your commander unit. Each race has its own Stronghold which if taken will kick them from the game for that campaign. Capture all strongholds to win.All in all the game looks great despite some age, it sounds great and has a decent soundtrack and its positively steeped in lore for every race. Theres dozens of novels written on this series. I highly recommend this game to any and all fans of RTS games. Gotta cut this one short since Steam wont let me write any more about this game! For the Emperor!

												This game is probrably the best RTS game ever.  With nine factions.  With completely seperate units, the developers took quite the amount of time and effort and it came out fantastic.  Rather simple to get the basics, but goes alot more in depth.  The campaign is amazing.  I mean come on.  Has there ever been a single RTS game where your mission is to rule a planet.  It sounds crazy and mediocre and boring, but the prologue makes sense.  Extremely time consuming with exciting fights against all other 8 factions.  Conquering their HQ won't be easy either.  You're up against a boss and waves and waves of coming units within the first minute of the turn.  And yes you take turns attacking and defending with a global view of the map.  You can have units defend territories or take them with you using requisition.  Upgrades are also availabe for your commander to get stronger and cooler.  It's finally suprising how the multiplayer for a game made in 2006 is still functioning!  The multiplayer with friends is a blast.  Use your strenths as different factions to either fight AI or other actual people!  In conclusion this game once again is one of the best RTS games i've seen.  Enough for me to buy 5 copies for my friends.  The price is also cheap and cheaper on sales.  Highly recommend!
